title: Digital Photograph, Hug Glove, Andrew Ellis and Susan Watts, 10 May 2020
creator: Ellis, Carolyn
description: Colour photograph (digital file) taken by Carolyn Ellis in Guelph during the national COVID-19 pandemic lockdown, 10 May 2020. The photograph depicts Andrew Ellis hugging his mother-in-law, Susan Watts, with the Hug Glove. Carolyn and Andrew Ellis created the Hug Glove to safely hug Susan Watts (Carolyn's mother) on Mother's Day during the COVID-19 pandemic. The original Hug Glove was made of vapour barrier plastic sheeting, Tuck Tape, and a clothes line. On Mother's Day 2020, Andrew took a video of Carolyn and Susan hugging with the Hug Glove [and posted it to Facebook]. The video went viral. Soon after, news stories reported people using "hug gloves" in nursing homes in Brazil, Spain, and Belgium. Before the pandemic, Susan Watts visited Andrew and Carolyn's family home daily to help with their two young boys. With the rising concerns over the pandemic, the Ellis family and Susan decided to go into lockdown. This was the first hug Andrew and Susan shared in two months. On March 11, 2020, the World Health Organization declared COVID-19 a pandemic. On March 17, Ontario declared a state of emergency. In Guelph, the lockdown prompted citywide closures and social distancing protocols. Between January 15, 2020 and June 12, 2021, there were 174,918,667 confirmed cases of COVID-19 with 3,782,490 deaths worldwide and 1,398,274 confirmed cases of COVID-19 with 25,873 deaths in Canada. Accessed June 12, 2021: https://covid19.who.int/ Between January 15, 2020 and June 12, 2021, there were 539,153 confirmed cases of COVID-19 with 8,950 deaths in Ontario and 2,837 confirmed cases of COVID-19 with 43 deaths in the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph public health unit. Accessed June 12, 2021: https://covid-19.ontario.ca/data

title: Digital Photograph, Alex Vander Vlugt, Black Lives Matter Solidarity March and Protest, 6 June 2020
creator: Vander Vlugt, Alex
description: Colour photograph (digital file) taken by Alex Vander Vlugt at the Black Lives Matter Solidarity March and Protest held on 6 June 2020. The photograph depicts a large crowd of protesters, who are marching down the centre of the street facing the camera. Leading the march and pictured in the centre of the frame is Kween, Executive Director, Guelph Black Heritage Society. Kween wears a "Black Lives Matter" t-shirt. She points toward the sky with her right arm fully extended. Many people are holding handmade protest signs. A large white banner with black text reads: "Not Another Black Life." On 6 June 2020, approximately 8,000 people gathered in downtown Guelph. The assembled crowd marched together in a peaceful protest organized by the Guelph Black Heritage Society in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement. Another 20,000 people followed the event through mainstream and social media platforms. This photograph is the source image for the alcohol ink artwork, titled "No Justice, No Peace" by artist Emily Vander Vlugt, which she gifted to the Guelph Black Heritage Society for fundraising purposes. A reproduction of the artwork is also held in Guelph Museums' collection.
